user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtSprintf:
```c
char *UtSprintf(const char *Spec, ...)
{
    va_list                     Args;
    static UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t Buf[UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS];
    static uint32               TextIndex = 0;

    ++TextIndex;
    if (TextIndex >= UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS)
        TextIndex = 0;

    va_start(Args, Spec);
    vsnprintf(Buf[TextIndex].Text, sizeof(Buf[TextIndex].Text), Spec, Args);
    va_end(Args);

    return Buf[TextIndex].Text;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtSprintf:
typedef struct
{
    char Text[UT_SNPRINTF_BUF_SIZE];
} UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t
...
#define UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS 10
...
static uint32               TextIndex = 0
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the provided UtSprintf function and the related symbol definitions. There is no use of the Standard Library function memcmp (neither directly nor via a visible macro or wrapper) in the shown code. The function uses va_list, vsnprintf and accesses a static char buffer; none of these invoke memcmp or compare null-terminated strings with memcmp. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14. If there are other source files or macros not shown that might call memcmp, those would need to be examined, but based on the provided code no suspicious fragments exist.
